channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Syriza Dissenters Form New Party in Greece
item.description: Hours after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras called early elections, 25 lawmakers created the Popular Unity party, and the opposition said it would try to form a new government.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Panagiotis Lafazanis, the leader of Syriza’s radical Left Platform faction, will head the new party Popular Unity.

item.title: Pair Who Attacked Hong Kong Journalist With Cleaver Sentenced to 19 Years
item.description: Kevin Lau Chun-to, who had recently been removed as chief editor of the Ming Pao newspaper, suffered severe cuts on his back and legs in the February 2014 assault.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kevin Lau Chun-to, a former editor of the newspaper Ming Pao, in May.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What Is Britain’s Labour Party For?
item.description: With Jeremy Corbyn ahead in the leadership race, we’re seeing a political movement unable to find new purpose.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK

item.title: Loudspeakers Seen as Trigger for Alert Between North and South Korea
item.description: Live fire directed into the South is being interpreted as a warning to stop blaring propaganda into the North, a Cold War tactic only recently revived.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers at a checkpoint just outside the Demilitarized Zone in Paju, South Korea, on Friday.

item.title: Head of Russian Railways, Close to Putin, Resigns
item.description: Vladimir I. Yakunin was seen as wielding vast power through the rail monopoly, and a relatively unknown technocrat was appointed to the post.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: After Nuclear Deal With West, Iran Gears Up to Cash In
item.description: Iranian officials have gone out of their way to emphasize that once sanctions are lifted, nothing stands in the way of foreigners snapping up assets.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sadjad Ghoroghi, who runs a mining company in Zanjan in northwestern Iran. He said he had long dreamed of finding a foreign investor willing to help expand his operations.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Court to Hear Suit Over Texts Calling Homosexuality an Illness
item.description: A communications student in the southern city of Guangzhou said she was shocked last year to discover textbooks that continued to define homosexuality as a sickness.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Chen Qiuyan, center, and four other students protesting the textbooks outside the Guangdong Education Department in March.

item.title: Seven Die as Planes Carrying Parachutists Collide Over Slovakia
item.description: The collision during a practice run for a coming air show killed four pilots and three parachutists, but 31 jumped to safety.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVÁ

item.title: Letter From Europe: BBC’s Status Helps Shield Broadcaster
item.description: "The question for David Cameron," a professor says, "is whether he wants to go down in history as the prime minister who effectively dismantled one of the world's most important cultural and democratic institutions."
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Britain to Reopen Embassy in Iran, Nearly 4 Years After It Was Ransacked
item.description: Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond is likely to reopen the embassy in Tehran on Sunday, in a significant indication of warming Western relations with Iran.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Iranian protesters ransacked the British Embassy in Tehran in 2011 and took down the British flag. The embassy is expected to reopen this weekend.

item.title: North Korea and South Korea Trade Fire Across Border, Seoul Says
item.description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un ordered his front-line military units to go on a “semi-war state” on Friday after South Korea said the two Koreas had exchanged rocket and artillery fire.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Koreans at a shelter in Yeoncheon County on Thursday. A county official said about 220 people were sent underground.

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Treason Charges for Spy
item.description: The officer, identified only as Markus R. because of privacy rules, is accused of offering his services to the C.I.A. in 2008 while working for Germany’s foreign intelligence agency.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Details Sexual Abuse Claims Against Troops
item.description: The United Nations said that nine of the 13 cases reported against its peacekeepers in the Central African Republic in the past year involved children as young as 11 and that no one had yet been convicted.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Responding to Rocket Fire, Israeli Forces Carry Out Strikes in Syria
item.description: Israel blamed Iran for the rocket attack on the Israeli-held part of the Golan Heights, a flare-up that appeared to be the most serious one in the area in months.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: In Letter, Obama Tells Congress U.S. Will Still Press Iran
item.description: The letter reflects a shift in emphasis, to steps the administration could take outside the nuclear agreement with Iran to enforce the deal’s provisions.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, announcing that he would not support the nuclear deal with Iran.

item.title: Crackdown in Niger Fails to Deter Migrant Smugglers
item.description: A new anti-trafficking law has done little to end the illicit migrant trade in Agadez, a departure point for as many as 2,000 Africans a week.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: West African migrants in Agadez, Niger, the last big stop before reaching Libya, 620 miles away, on their journey to Europe. As many as 2,000 migrants pass through the desert city each week.

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Pistorius Review Set
item.description: South Africa’s parole review board has up to four months to decide when Oscar Pistorius can be released from prison, the Justice Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Egyptians Adapt as Cairo Is Redefined by a String of Bomb Attacks
item.description: At least 29 people were wounded in an attack on a branch of the Egyptian security agency, adding to a wave of militant violence in the capital over the summer.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: House Speaker Is Charged
item.description: Prosecutors on Thursday filed corruption charges against Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of the lower house of Congress and one of Brazil’s most powerful political figures.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, Co-Founder of National Front, Is Ousted From French Far-Right Party
item.description: Jean-Marie Le Pen, who co-founded the National Front, was excluded on Thursday from the party following a disciplinary hearing.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Jean-Marie Le Pen after a hearing on Thursday at which he was excluded from the National Front.
